Issues.Title: fix(zone.js): patch `fs.realpath.native` as macrotask
Issues.Body:
This commit updates the implementation of the zone.js `fs` patch to restore the implementation of `realpath.native` and patches it as a macrotask, along with other functions of the `fs` package. This is the only nested function that must be patched.

Closes: #45546

Issues.Title: test(core): ExpressionChanged... error does not happen with signals
Issues.Body: This test ensures that the `ExpressionChanged...` error does not happen when signals are updated in a view that is attached to `ApplicationRef` but was already checked. This was fixed in 432afd1ef41e0bfd905e71e8b15ec7c9ab337352 which actually consequently fixes it for regular `markForCheck` as well.

Issues.Title: ExpressionChangedAfterItHasBeenCheckedError when setting value of signal in `ngOnInit`
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

core

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

Having two components which sets a value in `ngOnInit` ends in a `NG0100 ExpressionChangedAfterItHasBeenCheckedError`.

Im coming from the same issue when using NgRx in `ngOnInit` https://github.com/ngrx/platform/issues/3989

It is working though, when the code is moved to the constructor. but applying this "constructor rule" feels like its against the angular documentation https://angular.io/guide/lifecycle-hooks#oninit which says doing things in the constructor should be done in `ngOnInit`.
Coming from the above NgRx issue, there the NG100 error is exactly triggered when in `ngOnInit` an action is dispatched which triggers an effect which uses `HttpClient`. what essentially is the described case in the angular docs not doing in the constructor (http fetch).

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

https://stackblitz.com/edit/stackblitz-starters-om9ryw?file=src%2Fmain.ts

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

_No response_

### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
Angular 17.1.1
```


### Anything else?

I mean giving the advise not using fetch and therefore not being coupled to fetch in the constructor is good. but when dispatching an action which is an application of a loosely coupled design is valid in the constructor.
if you also have this opinion it would be worth mention this A) in the angular documentation (its ok to do loosely coupled things in the constructor) and B) in the NgRx documentation (do your dispatching in the constructor, its ok). @brandonroberts
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "ExpressionChangedAfterItHasBeenCheckedError when setting value of signal in `ngOnInit`" (#54197)

Issues.Title: Testing fails on 17.1.2 with a slightly older rxjs: export 'firstValueFrom' (imported as 'firstValueFrom') was not found in 'rxjs'
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

core

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

Running tests shows this error after updating to Angular 17.1.2 this morning (JST time).
```
./node_modules/@angular/core/fesm2022/testing.mjs:283:11-25 - Error: export 'firstValueFrom' (imported as 'firstValueFrom') was not found in 'rxjs' (possible exports: ArgumentOutOfRangeError, AsyncSubject, BehaviorSubject, ConnectableObservable, EMPTY, EmptyError, GroupedObservable, NEVER, Notification, NotificationKind, ObjectUnsubscribedError, Observable, ReplaySubject, Scheduler, Subject, Subscriber, Subscription, TimeoutError, UnsubscriptionError, VirtualAction, VirtualTimeScheduler, animationFrame, animationFrameScheduler, asap, asapScheduler, async, asyncScheduler, bindCallback, bindNodeCallback, combineLatest, concat, config, defer, empty, forkJoin, from, fromEvent, fromEventPattern, generate, identity, iif, interval, isObservable, merge, never, noop, observable, of, onErrorResumeNext, pairs, partition, pipe, queue, queueScheduler, race, range, scheduled, throwError, timer, using, zip)

It seems to be related to this change https://github.com/angular/angular/commit/3ca34e606d9bc11abe42bbb37c5d6a2b74dc17ea#diff-6d56fdd9ee4c67ada1b2c8ed428b61747b7dc5ad9158bd376ee7557b49281d5a.

We're on rxjs 6.6.7 currently, which seems to be in line with Angular's peer dependency ranges: `"^6.5.3 || ^7.4.0"`.

```

Issues.Title: v16+: Add option to publish a library built with ivy
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

compiler

### Description

I know that this idea has been rejected many times, such as [here](https://github.com/ng-packagr/ng-packagr/issues/1467) and [here](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/37973#issuecomment-656024069). In the last comment linked, it was said that 'By keeping the ivy internals private we can be more agile going forward.' Does the same situation still apply in 16+? Must we have no API such that full Ivy may be used when publishing libraries?

If all libraries must be compiled in `partial` mode forever, `full` mode being only available through workarounds, why are there multiple modes? Why make an option available if it will never be allowed?

### Proposed solution

This is more of a question than a critique. Ivy compilation was obviously designed to be more efficient, so if possible, the option should be made available.

### Alternatives considered

`partial` mode can be used in perpetuity. If this alternative is chosen, maybe the existence of `full` mode should be reconsidered.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "v16+: Add option to publish a library built with ivy" (#54205)

Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug? core ### Is this a regression? No ### Description I have a problem with a condition in SSR (Server-Side Rendering) related to "hydration." I have a condition based on the screen size, but I see my text content duplicating twice in mobile format. Issues.Title: Content projection
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

compiler

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

When using the new control-flow `@if` to display input suffixes or hints, it doesn't work as expected; instead, it's displayed inside the input (see screenshots). However, if I change it to use `*ngIf`, it works perfectly.

After many attempts, I've figured out that if I set `preserveWhitespaces: false` for the component, it also works with the new control-flow `@if`.

My question is, is there another way to handle this for the entire project? Any suggestions?

with `@if`:
![image](https://github.com/angular/angular/assets/31727552/66b9232c-eec1-427c-b72f-992eaf398eb5)

with `*ngIf`:
![image](https://github.com/angular/angular/assets/31727552/a91dd0a2-760e-4629-8bdf-db843c4b7c65)


Thanks

_No response_

Issues.Title: Exact supported Browserversions
Issues.Body:
### Describe the problem that you experienced

The docs state, that the 2 most recent chrome versions are supported. As chrome releases in a 4 week releasecycle it is pretty hard to determine which exactly are meant. 

### Enter the URL of the topic with the problem

https://angular.io/guide/browser-support

### Describe what you were looking for in the documentation

_No response_

### Describe the actions that led you to experience the problem

Customers ask us which browsers they need to use. As we are in an industrial environment, it's not given, they are always on the latest browsers

### Describe what you want to experience that would fix the problem

It would make sense to state the exact minimum browser version alongside the releases angular version.

Issues.Title: Create or define type for animation transition input
Issues.Body:
### Describe the problem that you experienced When you create a new animation that needs dynamic or calculated inputs, you'd do so using the syntax like so: ```html
``` I can only find this syntax defined in once place which is on the API docs page for the [transition](https://angular.io/api/animations/transition) function. Poking through the source code, I found where I believe this input is used in `transition_animation_engine.ts` with the class `StateValue` ([link](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/animations/browser/src/render/transition_animation_engine.ts#L106)). In that source file, `value` is typed in the constructor code as `any` (as seen with the input and return types of the `normalizeTriggerValue` function). In the field declarations of the class however, it is typed as a `string`. Likewise the `input` property for the constructor is typed as `any`. ### Enter the URL of the topic with the problem _No response_ ### Describe what you were looking for in the documentation When looking through the documentation, I was looking for what inputs are accepted for the animation trigger binding. All I could find was this excerpt from the Introduction page: > Then, you can bind the trigger to a template expression using standard Angular property binding syntax as shown below, where triggerName is the name of the trigger, and expression evaluates to a defined animation state. ### Describe the actions that led you to experience the problem In my project, I have on the lint rule that requires all functions to have a defined return type. That proved difficult when I was trying to define functions that return the state name and animation params like so: ```typescript @HostBinding('@rotateIcon') get rotateIconBinding() { return this.rotateDegrees === 0 ? this.getDefaultAnimationState : this.getRotatedAnimationState; } protected get getDefaultAnimationState() { return { value: 'default', params: { rotateDegrees: this.rotateDegrees } }; } protected get getRotatedAnimationState() { return { value: 'rotated', params: { rotateDegrees: this.rotateDegrees } }; } ``` ### Describe what you want to experience that would fix the problem Any (preferably all) of the following would help alleviate the issue for me or others that are struggling with the state of the current animation docs: 1. Create a type definition for the `input` property of `StateValue` like so: ```typescript import { AnimationOptions } from '@angular/animations'; export type AnimationStateInput = string | ({ value: string } & AnimationOptions); ``` 2. Add a section in the Introduction docs explaining what inputs can be provided (aka the name or an object defined like step 1) The above solutions would fix the documentation problem, but it would also be fantastic if there was some sort of IDE support that could detect available animation states so that when you work with animations, it detects issues at compile time. ### Add a screenshot if that helps illustrate the problem _No response_ ### If this problem caused an exception or error, please paste it here _No response_ ### If the problem is browser-specific, please specify the device, OS, browser, and version _No response_ ### Provide any additional information here in as much as detail as you can _No response_

Issues.Title: feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): allow control of Vite-based development server prebundling
Issues.Body: Previously, the Vite-based development server that is automatically used with the `application` and `browser-esbuild` builders would always use prebundling if the Angular CLI caching was enabled. The development server now has a specific `prebundle` option to allow more control over prebundling while still allowing other forms of caching within the Angular CLI. The `prebundle` option can be a boolean value of `true` or `false` that will enable or disable prebundling, respectively. Additionally, the option also has an object long-form. This long-form enables prebundling and currently contains one property named `exclude`. The `exclude` property supports cases where a package should not be prebundled and rather should be bundled directly into the application code. These cases are not common but can happen based on project specific requirements. If the `prebundle` option is enabled when using the `browser` builder or any other Webpack-based builder, it will be ignored as the Webpack-based development server does not contain such functionality.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): allow control of Vite-based development server prebundling" (#27021)

Issues.Title: Incorrect case-sensitivity in `ng generate` CLI console/info output
Issues.Body:
### Command

generate

### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

While creating a new component with the command

     ng generate component Admin/Accounts

it'll output:

```
CREATE src/app/Admin/accounts/accounts.component.scss (0 bytes)
CREATE src/app/Admin/accounts/accounts.component.html (23 bytes)
CREATE src/app/Admin/accounts/accounts.component.spec.ts (610 bytes)
CREATE src/app/Admin/accounts/accounts.component.ts (243 bytes)
```

Apparently it will print out the `Admin` part of the path while generating the module, however the resulting files are correctly created lower-case at `src/app/admin/...`.

Probably just a missing lowercase-conversion in the CLI output.



### Minimal Reproduction

In an empty project, create two components.

    $ ng generate component FirstCompo


    $ ng generate component FirstCompo/SecondCompo

### Exception or Error

```text
The output should correctly print the created path with the correct case.
```


### Your Environment

```text
Clean docker node environment.
```


### Anything else relevant?

_No response_

Issues.Title: feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): add JSON build logs when using the application builder
Issues.Body:
This change implements the capability to display JSON build logs in the terminal instead of a format readable by humans. This is particularly useful for hosting providers, as it allows them to effortlessly access the necessary information without having to parse the JSON configuration.

To enable this output, set the `NG_BUILD_LOGS_JSON=1` environment variable. Additionally, warnings, errors, and logs are automatically colorized when the standard output is a WritableStream. You can disable the colors by using the `FORCE_COLOR=0` environment variable.

```
FORCE_COLOR=0 NG_BUILD_LOGS_JSON=1 ng b
{
  "errors": [],
  "warnings": [],
  "outputPaths": {
    "base": "file:///usr/local/test/home//test-project/dist/test-project",
    "browser": "file:///usr/local/test/home//test-project/dist/test-project/browser",
    "server": "file:///usr/local/test/home//test-project/dist/test-project/server"
  },
  "serverEntryFile": "file:///usr/local/test/home//test-project/dist/test-project/server/server.mjs",
  "prerenderedRoutes": [
    "/"
  ]
}
```

```
NG_BUILD_LOGS_JSON=1 ng b
{
  "errors": [],
  "warnings": [],
  "outputPaths": {
    "base": "file:///usr/local/test/home//test-project/dist/test-project",
    "browser": "file:///usr/local/test/home//test-project/dist/test-project/browser",
    "server": "file:///usr/local/test/home//test-project/dist/test-project/server"
  },
  "serverEntryFile": "file:///usr/local/test/home//test-project/dist/test-project/server/server.mjs",
  "prerenderedRoutes": [
    "/"
  ]
}
```

Issues.Title: feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): support using custom postcss configuration with application builder
Issues.Body:
When using the `application` builder, the usage of a custom postcss configuration is now supported. The builder will automatically detect and use specific postcss configuration files if present in either the project root directory or the workspace root. Files present in the project root will have priority over a workspace root file. If using a custom postcss configuration file, the automatic tailwind integration will be disabled. To use both a custom postcss configuration and tailwind, the tailwind setup must be included in the custom postcss configuration file.

The configuration files must be JSON and named one of the following:
* `postcss.config.json`
* `.postcssrc.json`

A configuration file can use either an array form or an object form to setup plugins. An example of the array form:
```
{
    "plugins": [
        "tailwindcss",
        ["rtlcss", { "useCalc": true }]
    ]
}
```

The same in an object form:
```
{
    "plugins": {
        "tailwindcss": {},
        "rtlcss": { "useCalc": true }
    }
}
```

NOTE: Using a custom postcss configuration may result in reduced build and rebuild
performance. Postcss will be used to process all global and component stylesheets
when a custom configuration is present. Without a custom postcss configuration,
postcss is only used for a stylesheet when tailwind is enabled and the stylesheet
requires tailwind processing.

Closes #25411
Closes #26867
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): support using custom postcss configuration with application builder" (#27000)

Issues.Title: Application/Vite builder does not work with linked libraries and cache enabled
Issues.Body:
### Command

serve

### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

When rebuilding a linked library, the `ng serve` does not pick the changes of that library when we have cache enabled.

I tried to include the linked library under the `paths` config in ` tsconfig.json` but it made the library chunk get imported twice during runtime. In the chrome dev-tools I can see the library generated chunk being imported from `.angular/cache/17.1.1/vite/deps` and another chunk from the same library at the `root`.

It is possible to make this work by any means? Not having the possibility to have cache enabled really hurts.

### Minimal Reproduction

1. Prepare the environment:
```bash
ng new my-workspace --create-application false
ng new my-app

cd ./my-workspace
ng generate library my-lib
ng build my-lib

cd ../my-app
npm link ../my-worksapce/dist/my-lib
```

2. Import and use the linked library in the `app.component.ts`:
```ts
import { Component } from '@angular/core';
import { RouterOutlet } from '@angular/router';

import { MyLibComponent } from 'my-lib';

@Component({
  selector: 'app-root',
  standalone: true,
  imports: [RouterOutlet],
  templateUrl: './app.component.html',
  styleUrl: './app.component.css'
})
export class AppComponent {
  title = 'my-app';

  constructor() {
    console.log(MyLibComponent);
  }
}
```

3. Run `ng serve` - The component class is printed in the browser console.
4. Change something in the linked library component `MyLibComponent` and rebuild it with `ng build my-lib --watch` - The change is not applied to the application.

_No response_

serve

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

16.2.0

### Description

After updating an Angular application to version 17 and switching the build system from webpack (@angular-devkit/build-angular:browser) to esbuild (@angular-devkit/build-angular:browser-esbuild), the application fails to make successful API calls that were previously working. The same setup continues to work without issues when reverted back to the webpack builder

### Minimal Reproduction

**Steps to Reproduce**

1.Update an existing Angular project to version 17.
2.Change the build architect in angular.json to use "builder": "@angular-devkit/build-angular:browser-esbuild".
2.Run ng serve --proxy-config proxy.conf.js (with appropriate proxy settings).
3.Observe that API calls that go through the Angular proxy setup fail to reach the backend.

**Expected Behavior**
The application should be able to make API calls through the Angular proxy setup using esbuild, similar to how it functions with the webpack builder.

**Actual Behavior**
The application fails to communicate with the backend when using the esbuild builder, with API calls returning parsing errors indicating that the requests are not reaching the backend.

**Additional Information**

The proxy setup is confirmed to be correct and works as expected with the webpack builder.
No errors are logged in the console that provide insight into why the esbuild build process might be failing

Issues.Title: fix(material-experimental/theming): Make color API back-cmpat styles available
Issues.Body:
Depends on https://github.com/angular/components/pull/28516

Also changes our back-compat styles to make chips and options with `.mat-primary` secondary colored rather than primary. This sounds odd, but the spec really treats "secondary" as an extended set of primary hues, and these components look much better when defaulted to secondary.

A user who really does want the primary color can still get it by calling e.g. `@include mat.chips-theme($theme, $color-variant: primary)`, this only affects what our back-compat mixin outputs (`@include matx.color-variants-back-compat($theme)`).

Issues.Title: bug(legacy/MDC-migration): catch-22 when trying to run the migration script
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

# TL;DR:

The legacy component migration script `ng generate @angular/material:mdc-migration` has a bug in v16 that was only fixed in v17. But you can't upgrade to v17 if you have legacy components. Reductio ad absurdum!

It would be great if a v16 release of the one-line fix from https://github.com/angular/components/pull/28342 could be made.


# Description
The current v16 release of `@angular/material` has a bug that does not allow the mdc migraiton script to run:
```
$ npx ng generate @angular/material:mdc-migration
? What components do you want to migrate? 
Schematic input does not validate against the Schema: {"directory":false,"components":[]}
Errors:

  Data path "/directory" must be string.
```
This was fixed in https://github.com/angular/components/pull/28342 and released in 17.1.0-rc.0.  The one-line fix works for me on 16.2.13.

# Workaround

Manually apply https://github.com/angular/components/pull/28342/commits/317eba07c2874064ea59c3607396453f8993c35a

### Reproduction

N/A


### Expected Behavior

`ng generate @angular/material:mdc-migration`  should run

### Actual Behavior

Issues.Title: [Cherry pick] fix(material/schematics): schema error in mdc migration
Issues.Body:
Cherry-picks the fix for the MDC migration to the 16.2.x branch.

[A recent change in the CLI](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/pull/26685) added a `-d` flag to `ng generate` which is the same as the alias for `--directory` in the MDC migration. This caused an error, because the default boolean value from the CLI was being picked up and was failing the schema validation.

These changes remove the alias since it isn't really necessary.

Fixes #28510.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "[Cherry pick] fix(material/schematics): schema error in mdc migration" (#28520)

Issues.Title: feat(changelog-generation): Changelog generation
Issues.Body:
### Feature Description

Hello,

I apologize in advance for the most probably incorrect section for my suggestion or request.

I have been doing some digging and I really enjoy the way Angular and the Material Components specifically generate their CHANGELOG based on the [convention-changelog](https://github.com/conventional-changelog/conventional-changelog).

I wanted to ask if you could provide me with the exact script/tools you are using in order to generate your CHANGELOG automatically between two tags. Since you support multiple versions (16.0.x, 17.0.x, etc.) it stands to reason to be able to generate a separate changelog for each of them based on the changes only for that version.

Our organization follows the same commit message patterns and was inspired by Angular, however we want to move with automatic CHANGELOG generation based on those commits (feat/fix/chore/etc.).
I cannot seem to find the exact piece of code that you use in order to trigger this process, so any assistance would be highly appreciated!

P.S.
Such guidance would definitely be extremely useful to other people and organization who want to use the same approach as you do and I personally would be more than thrilled to share my experience and even document it!

Thank you!

### Use Case

_No response_

Issues.Title: docs(material/dialog): use h2 for dialog title
Issues.Body:
Because the vast majority of pages will already have an `<h1>`, and MDN now recommends to avoid using multiple `<h1>` elements on one page. So we should strive to show code examples that can be copy-pasted as is.

See also:

- https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/Heading_Elements#avoid_using_multiple_h1_elements_on_one_page
- https://stackoverflow.com/a/38467898/37706
- https://accessibleweb.com/question-answer/how-should-i-handle-headings-in-a-modal/
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "docs(material/dialog): use h2 for dialog title" (#28519)

Issues.Title: docs(material/dialog): use element selector instead of attribute selector
Issues.Body:

- at least as much semantically correct as the div used until now

- by far the most used in this repository
- the only selector explicitly mentioned on https://material.angular.io/components/dialog/overview#dialog-content

![image](https://github.com/angular/components/assets/15703819/7cd4ad11-909f-4cd4-8cb0-8a0c48b8aa48)

What could help is to add `flex: 1` style to `.mat-mdc-menu-item-text`.

2. observe the truncated icon in the third Menu Item
